text: Night had fallen, and the wind whispered past the lanterns at the street corner.
Footprints cut sharply through the snow outside the inn, leading into the darkness.
Inside, only the crackling of the hearth broke the silence—the firelight flickering against the wooden walls.
The door burst open. A gust of cold wind swept in, scattering embers and making the flames shudder.
Lucia stumbled in, breath ragged, snow still clinging to her hair.
“Innkeeper—my mentor, she’s in trouble!”
“Alicia? What happened—slow down.”
I stepped out from behind the counter, voice tightening without meaning to.
“She went to help patch up one of the town guards.”
Lucia bit her lip, voice trembling. “I waited outside… but not long after she went in, a few men in black robes followed her.”
“And then—she never came out.”
I frowned. “Black robes?”
“They had the same mark on their chests.”
She traced a ring-shaped symbol in the air with a trembling finger. “It was the mark of the Echo Circle—it was supposed to be disbanded!”
My stomach dropped. I remembered that name well—years ago, they’d been declared heretics by the crown for ‘experiments using souls as material.’
I didn’t waste another thought. My hand went for the short sword under the counter.
“Let’s go.”
Lucia followed, voice shaking. “You… you can fight, right?”
I paused for a moment, breathing deep.
“No,” I said quietly, steady. “But I owe Alicia a life—and I won’t owe her a second.”
The streets were veiled in fog, snow crunching underfoot with every step.
The wind carried ash from the rooftops, and the lanterns swayed weakly in the storm.
We followed Alicia’s footprints north, through the silent alleys, until they ended at the Scrap Alley.
The houses there were half-collapsed, the iron gates bent, rust like dried blood clinging to the hinges.
I raised a hand, signaling Lucia to stop.
The snow was eerily quiet. From beneath us came a low, rhythmic sound—someone was chanting.
Not prayer, but something colder. Mechanical. Ritualistic.
Lucia held her breath. “That’s… the cadence of a ritual.”
She looked up, face pale. “She’s still alive.”
“Then we save her.”
Lucia nodded, lifting her staff as a faint light gathered in her palm.
The wind brushed the iron latch—click.
We descended the dark stairwell, one careful step at a time.
The air reeked of iron and ash, the walls casting long, cold shadows under the blue glow.
Several robed figures stood around a glowing circle, chanting in unison.
At the center, Alicia was bound to a stone pillar, her amulet flickering weakly.
“Mentor…” Lucia whispered.
She raised her staff, light pooling at her fingertips.
“Prepare for battle,” she said, her voice shaking—but she didn’t back down.

options.text: Option A: Charge in head-on! [Strength Check DC 15]
Option B: Create a distraction to let Lucia rescue her. [Dexterity Check DC 12]
Option C: Try to talk to them—buy time if you can. [Charisma Check DC 13]
